11.text:
>> Dr. Frank Lamas: I have the pleasure this
morning to introduce Ken O'Donnell. Ken O'Donnell

18.text:
is the Senior Director of Student Engagement
and Academic Initiatives and Partnerships

22.text:
at the Office of the Chancellor of California
State University. He's a prominent figure

28.text:
nationally in this area. Many CSU students,
as you know, are under-represented minorities,

34.text:
economically disadvantaged, and are first
in their families to go to college. Ken works

41.text:
on statewide curriculum with a focus on student
engagement and success. He oversees offices

49.text:
that focus on projects to strengthen STEM
education, community engagement, transfer

55.text:
and articulation agreements, general education,
and all things improving learning, persistence,

62.text:
and closing the achievement gaps. The Department's
work has been recognized in 2013 by AASCU

69.text:
publication, "Bringing High Impact Practices
to Scale," which he co-wrote with George Kuh,

75.text:
another prominent figure in this area. The
CSU has continued to lead national efforts

81.text:
to define, track, and assess the impact of
engaging educational strategies like learning

88.text:
communities, service learning, peer mentoring,
supplemental instruction, undergraduate research.

95.text:
Bringing more students in having that benefit
in their education. Fresno State is so appreciative

102.text:
to have someone of Ken's stature here today.
And we appreciate him taking time away from

108.text:
all the things that he does. And we also appreciate
the Chancellor's office for additional funding

114.text:
that we received for student success initiatives
that supplement the funds that we put here

120.text:
at Fresno State. It is my pleasure to introduce
Ken, and to thank our system for all the work

127.text: they do with us here. Thank you.

133.text:
>> Dr. Ken O'Donnell: Thanks for that; that
was a lovely introduction. Really nice. I

144.text:
want to thank you folks for being here and
for inviting me. This is a privilege. What's

151.text:
going on at Fresno State is really remarkable.
I'm looking forward to spending the rest of

159.text:
the day with you and learning more first-hand
about how you're pulling this off. And I'm

165.text:
going to share with you some thoughts from
the system level about the importance of this

169.text:
work. But before I do, I want to pick up on
something that you just heard Frank Lamas

173.text:
mention, which is the money that the System
Office sends around for student success. For

178.text:
a while, that was our Chancellor's discretion.
He was doing that because he believed in it,

184.text:
and we were pulling out of a horrible recession
that had cut many of the things that our students

189.text:
count on the most to succeed. And so he set
aside several million in different pots of

196.text:
money that we were able to distribute. We
asked the campuses at the time to keep track

201.text:
of what the benefits were from investments
like that. And Fresno did an unusually good

208.text:
job of helping us tell our story. And so today
the latest increment we got for student success

215.text:
funding, it wasn't a few million dollars because
the Chancellor felt strongly about it. It

219.text:
was from the State of California. And it's
because the commitment that you are sensing

225.text:
this morning to really help all our students
to succeed, to close those achievement gaps.

233.text:
It's infectious. And it's visible. And it's
working. It's helping us support the work

239.text:
that most matters to our students. So thank
you for that. It was one of the main reasons

244.text:
that I really jumped at the chance to come
here. So I'm going to share with you some

249.text:
thoughts about student success that will echo
the comments you heard just now from your

254.text:
Vice Presidents and from your President around
student success at the institutional level.

263.text:
Not just in your own personal interactions
with students, but really how is that coordinated

268.text:
so that the experience for your students is
relatively seamless. It's really hard to do.

275.text:
So I'm going to talk about high impact practices.
And then data, the point that I was raising

283.text:
before where I think you folks are especially
strong. And then finally, equity. Before I

289.text:
do, I'm going to share with you just a little
bit of the CSU story at the state level, to

295.text:
give you some context of my work and where
this impression is coming from. So here's

301.text:
our seal, and here's our mission. I'm going
to quote to you -- this is from our web page.

305.text:
This is calstate.edu. You probably don't have
it bookmarked in your browser. So I won't

313.text:
ask you to join in a recitation. Instead,
I'll just put it up on screen. So number one

319.text:
in our mission, "To prepare significant numbers
of educated, responsible people to contribute

327.text:
to California's schools, economy, culture,
and future." That's it. I mean, don't feel

343.text:
any pressure. It's kind of in our hands. And
then the second bullet point in this mission

352.text:
that I'm especially proud of: "To encourage
and provide access to an excellent education

363.text:
to all who are prepared for and wish to participate
in collegiate study." In those two bullet

372.text:
points is the tension and the magic of the
work we do. That it's really good, that it's

382.text:
really good for the State. And that it's,
to an unprecedented degree, available to a

389.text:
wide range of people. The intellectual and
personal development we offer to the whole

396.text:
spectrum of the people who live in California,
I find moving. I really do. And so it bugs

406.text:
me when we don't do better, when we don't
have higher graduation rates. When we have

410.text:
persistent achievement gaps. It really does
kind of haunt me. And I suspect it haunts

415.text:
many of us. And so this intentional, concerted
work you folks are doing in cooperation with

421.text:
each other to fix that is important. It's
meaningful. I'm going to quote our web page

429.text:
with one other fact for you. Here's what we
contribute to the State of California. Now,

434.text:
note this chart is not, what are the degrees
we produce. This is, of the people who work

439.text:
in California in these industries, how many
of those degrees were earned at the CSU? And

447.text:
so what you see is, well over half of the
people who work in agriculture, hospitality

453.text:
and tourism and business are CSU alumni. More
than half. And you've probably had this experience

463.text:
too. As I travel around, I know there are
certain people I'll interact with where the

468.text:
odds are better than half that when they see
my business card or when I register for something,

474.text:
they'll go, "Oh, I went to the CSU." It's
a huge, huge reach. And those are our big

480.text:
output, the contributions to the state -- agriculture,
business, health/medicine, hospitality, tourism,

485.text:
engineering, media, culture and design. And
like you heard earlier, these were a lot of

490.text:
folks who didn't even plan to go to college.
Those are really good jobs. That's kind of

495.text:
out the back door. Coming in the front door,
that mission of access. Californians from

501.text:
different ethnic, socioeconomic and educational
backgrounds. Making it the most diverse university

507.text:
system in the country. And this is a country
that's getting more and more diverse all the

511.text:
time. So they look at us to figure out how
to do better. We are their future. CSU has

520.text:
significant academic preparation and outreach
programs. Like that barnstorming tour you

525.text:
just heard about through the central valley.
Reaching out to those communities, making

531.text:
sure they understand they really are welcome
here. And here's how best to position yourself

535.text:
to succeed. And then on top of that we have
a massive transfer mission. Every year the

542.text:
graduating class at the system level, more
than 60% of them began somewhere else, almost

548.text:
all of them at California community colleges.
So some of those programs that can set our

554.text:
teeth on edge, like Associate degrees for
transfer. Where all of a sudden we're like

560.text:
bending our curriculum to try to fit some
abstracted model of what curriculum should

565.text:
look like. There's an upside to that. You
know, it's painful and it doesn't always end

571.text:
up where you feel like your students are in
a better place than they were at the beginning.

576.text:
But on the whole, at the State level, that's
such a win as far as the access, the affordability,

584.text:
the ability of a student to finish in a reasonable
amount of time. So that's kind of who we are

595.text:
and what we're up to. About a month ago, the
Chancellor, Tim White, was giving an address

600.text:
he gives every year in January called "The
State of the CSU." This is his performance

607.text:
report to his bosses. He makes this report
to the Board of Trustees. It's heavily covered

613.text:
by the press. This headline says, "CSU Chancellor,
Timothy White evokes moon race in charting

622.text: the future." Here's what he said.

652.text:
So I work on student success. I work on the
graduation initiative. And I heard that, and

656.text:
I just thought, are you kidding me? Do you
have any idea how baked into the system those

667.text:
gaps are? The CSU, by the time we get them
they're 18 at the youngest. We're supposed

675.text:
to overcome a lifetime of societal inequity?
Of imbalances in school districts? Of different

682.text:
cultural expectations? But then my second
thought was, what if we did? I mean, if anyone

693.text:
can do it it's us. And in fact there are pockets
of work on this very campus. On this very

706.text:
campus, where that has happened. I will get
to that in a moment. First, here's that "High

716.text:
Impact Practices" book. Around the time we
launched our graduation initiative, this book

721.text:
came out. Written by George Kuh, whose name
you heard Frank Lamas use a moment ago. And

726.text:
what he was talking about under the label,
"high impact practices" was really stuff most

732.text:
of us have known about for a lot longer than
the time since this book came out. It's just

736.text:
what happens when you get students up out
of their chairs, right? It's experiential

741.text:
learning. It's hands-on learning. It's internships.
The list is -- there's civic engagement, service

749.text:
learning, peer mentoring, learning communities,
work-based learning, collaborating with faculty

756.text:
on their research. We used to think of these
as all different. Some of them were for students

762.text:
who were struggling. Some were for your star
students if you wanted to pull them aside

765.text:
and put them in a lab with you. What this
book claimed was that these various high-impact

771.text:
practices actually have some properties in
common that hadn't been noticed before. They

779.text:
improve persistence. They improve learning.
And they even seem to have a disproportionate

786.text:
benefit for the students who are least likely
to succeed. Because of their academic records,

794.text:
because they're from backgrounds where higher
ed has just had a very hard time serving students

799.text:
from those backgrounds. In other words, they
were grad rate boosters. And gap closers.

805.text:
And since we had just launched our graduation
initiative where those were our two goals,

809.text:
we had to pay attention. And the director
of institutional research at one of our campuses,

814.text:
Cal State-Northridge, correlated student survey
data with student graduation rate data to

821.text:
see if it was true. And the survey was, did
you participate in any of these high-impact

826.text:
practices? And then the graduate data, she
would just match that back to the records

830.text:
to see if they ever got out. Here's what she
found. The number at the base of each of those

837.text:
columns is how many high-impact practices
the students had reported participating in.

845.text:
And what you see is, when it's zero the six-year
grad rate is 38% for the Latino students and

851.text:
55 for everybody else. Pretty typical for
the CSU. But then look what happens when they

860.text:
participate in one. And look at what happens
at two. At both the rate and the difference

868.text:
in those rates. That's down to a three-point
difference. So we were pretty excited. We

877.text:
had this national publication saying, here's
a way to have it both ways. You can run up

882.text:
your grad rates and close your gaps. And you're
not watering anything down. In fact, you're

889.text:
making it more engaging, more rigorous, more
compelling. That's what's bringing them back.

894.text:
Because learning this way, as you know if
you've been involved in high-impact practices,

899.text:
it's hard. It's really challenging. It's exhausting.
But at the end of it you feel like you grew,

903.text:
and you want to try it again. That's what
we were finding. And yet -- I don't have to

910.text:
tell you because you're all educated critical
thinkers -- there's all kinds of problems

914.text:
with this data. Some of it may already have
occurred to you, like selection bias, right?

921.text:
Like if I'm looking at the kids who signed
up for two high impact practices, aren't I

926.text:
looking at the kids who are going to graduate
no matter what? Northridge could have offered

932.text:
no high impact practices and those kids were
going to graduate. So you can't really talk

937.text:
about cause and effect. Now, the IR director
there had done some work to control for such

942.text:
things, matching students apples-to-apples
by academic preparation, by other elements

948.text:
in their background other than Latino or not.
And so we're pretty confident that she had

953.text:
ironed out as much of that as she can. But
the suspicion still has to remain that you

958.text:
can't really hang a whole policy on it. Second,
it's survey data. So years after the fact,

964.text:
you're asking a graduating senior, did you
ever do a freshman learning community? And

969.text:
they're like, oh, yeah. So there too, you
don't really want to hang a policy on it.

978.text:
I would say that what you can say about this
chart is that it tells a hopeful story about

984.text:
the intersection between powerful learning
and student success. The same intersection

989.text:
that I would say is epitomized in this very
meeting. Because it's co-hosted by your Provost

996.text:
and your Vice President of Student Affairs.
In that intersection, in that cooperation

1001.text:
across divisions that in most higher ed institutions
don't cooperate all that often, is where the

1007.text:
magic happens. Is where the student experience
materially changes. And suddenly they're pulled

1014.text:
into it. That's what we thought we saw in
this. Or at least this gave us plausible reason

1024.text:
to confirm what many of us who've ever taught
already believed intuitively. Like, you've

1029.text:
had that experience when you interact with
students. So we set about with an increment

1036.text:
of funding from the Chancellor to try to answer
this question. What if we didn't have to ask

1042.text:
the students on a survey years later, "Did
you ever do such-and-such?" What if we could

1046.text:
just keep track of it? Really rigorously and
unambiguously. It's hard to do. If you ask

1054.text:
a roomful of a thousand faculty members and
student affairs people, do you do high-impact

1060.text:
practices? A thousand hands will go into the
air, right? No one's going to say, no, I'm

1067.text:
actually proud of my low-impact work for students.
So we had to have something where you could

1074.text:
say yes or no. This one is. This one might
be very good, but it doesn't count by this

1081.text:
metric. So this student is in our control
group. It's a necessary first step, is having

1088.text:
hard conversations. At the institutional level.
About what counts. What do we all believe

1097.text:
makes a difference? So we convened the recipients
of one of the Chancellor's allocations a couple

1105.text:
of years ago. To develop definitions of these
where you could actually test the student

1110.text:
experience against the definition and end
up with a yes or no, did this happen? And

1115.text:
they were from different campuses. So we were
trying to wash out local idiosyncrasies. And

1120.text:
we developed these things called "taxonomies."
Many of you in this room were involved in

1124.text:
those. At the top part of the page is the
bare minimum definition. You've got to have

1128.text:
these three things. I think that one is Summer
Bridge. Yes, so the Summer Bridge bare minimum

1134.text:
definition? Has to happen in the summer. Has
to be a bridge to academics, right? It can't

1144.text:
just be get acquainted with the campus and
then go home, it's really got to bridge the

1148.text:
student from high school to college. And if
it's not doing that, it may still be good.

1153.text:
It's nice when they can find their way around.
Just please don't call it "Summer Bridge,"

1157.text:
or you'll mess up our data. And then the bottom
part, those low intensity, medium intensity,

1164.text:
high intensity columns, that's where you can
tell us the local story. So we have Summer

1169.text:
Bridge, it passes those four tests. And then
within that we have an unusually high amount

1175.text:
of faculty involvement. And an unusually low
amount of days on campus, because we're in

1181.text:
a remote area. But it works for us. That was
kind of what we were picturing. And you can

1190.text:
find them. I mean, they're all posted at that
web page if you ever want to download, customize

1195.text:
them. They're kind of like, A, A, C, and U
value rubrics where they're posted in Word.

1199.text:
So that if you don't like the phrasing or
something doesn't work for you, you can use

1203.text:
them. We didn't really plan to roll it all
up to the system level. It was more of a tool

1208.text:
for campuses to use, which is what I think
it has become. So that's the high-impact practices

1216.text:
end of what I'm going to talk about. At the
end of defining them rigorously, though, the

1219.text:
whole point is that you want some data of
their efficacy. And not just, do they work?

1225.text:
But for whom? And when in their educational
career? So that you can target them where

1232.text:
they're going to have the biggest benefit.
This is an article from the Los Angeles Times

1239.text:
about a year ago. One of my favorite education
reporters, and it's not even an education

1245.text:
journal. This is Carla Rivera at the Los Angeles
Times. I don't know if you've ever been interviewed

1251.text:
by her. I don't recommend it. She's like really
smart. Like I'll be on the phone with her

1261.text:
and I'll say something and she'll go, "Huh,
really? Because six months ago you said it

1264.text:
wasn't." And I'm like, "Oh, I have another
call. Bye." So get a load of this headline.

1274.text:
Which I think epitomizes how sophisticated
she is. "Gauging the value of colleges' community

1279.text:
service programs can be tough." Now, Fresno
is a leader in this. You guys years ago passed

1287.text:
the million hour mark. That was a big deal
for those of you who worked here then. Chris

1291.text:
Fiorentino continues to run that office with
great passion and effectiveness. The article

1298.text:
quotes Chris's counterpart at Dominguez Hills.
Cheryl McKnight runs service learning there.

1303.text:
And she says this about service learning.
[Silence] And that's another thing that I

1318.text:
think the data around high-impact practices
would benefit from looking at. Yes, it improves

1326.text:
learning. And it improves persistence. We
know we can see the benefits if we look hard

1330.text:
enough in GPA and grad rates. But if that's
all you're looking for, some of these things

1337.text:
are going to be at the bottom of the list.
But they belong at the top. We know that intuitively.

1343.text:
We know that this is a big part of what college
is for. And we believe it's true. Not just

1350.text:
of service learning, but a lot of high-impact
practices. The students, they come into themselves.

1358.text:
Could you picture a world where we could prove
it? Where you could do learning outcomes assessment

1367.text:
of the kind that just won you your ten-year
reaccreditation? But where the learning includes

1373.text:
dispositional attitude, things like creativity.
Here's the way we often think about assessment.

1386.text:
On that column are the various interventions
we might try. And then we'll look at persistence,

1391.text:
grade point average. And we'll start to look
at, okay, what's helping here? And those things,

1397.text:
they're pretty much all going to be helping.
But then we might get more sophisticated and

1403.text:
ask, what do they know? Could we get it to
that level of learning outcomes assessment?

1408.text:
It's had a head start. We've probably had
things about what students can demonstrate

1412.text:
they know and do for several decades by now.
And on that one, you could see different interventions

1418.text:
having different benefits. Especially the
ones connected to traditional courses. But

1424.text:
what if we got also to the kinds of outcomes
that Cheryl described? What if we got to creativity?

1432.text:
Agency? Then we would see that some of the
other high-impact practices belong at the

1439.text:
top of the list. I think we want to know.
I think that as the State of California asks

1447.text:
us to justify the soaring expense of higher
education, we should have a better story to

1454.text:
tell than just, they stayed in the seat and
got out. And it should even be better than,

1463.text:
we contribute more than half of the State's
engineers. We should also be able to tell

1470.text:
them something about the benefits of this
personal development that we offer. This liberating

1475.text:
experience of higher education. And we can
get there. We can get to that assessment side.

1484.text:
Especially if we get our inputs shored up
with that record creation step. So that it's

1487.text:
not just survey data years later, but we're
actually tracking it as we go along. There's

1492.text:
a step in between that I want to share with
you. And that has to do with information technology,

1497.text:
the student record-keeping, the IT, the PeopleSoft.
This example comes from Cal State-Fullerton.

1507.text:
They did one of those soul-searching institution-wide
conversations about what are the high-impact

1512.text:
practices that seem to work for us? And as
you may know about Cal State-Fullerton, it

1519.text:
is not a typical CSU. It's huge. It is huge.
They've got somewhere between 30 and 35 thousand

1527.text:
students. In the middle of Orange County.
Big -- you can feel lost when you start there.

1534.text:
Especially if you're coming from a small high
school, small community college. So these

1537.text:
were the five they singled out. It says Undergraduate
Research, Freshman Programs, Supplemental

1543.text:
Instruction, Study Abroad Programs, and Residence
Halls. Residence Halls. That is nowhere in

1551.text:
the national literature for high-impact practices.
That's a heresy. Residence Halls, really?

1557.text:
You're calling that a high-impact practice?
And then I talked to them about this heresy.

1561.text:
I'm like, you know, really, you shouldn't
be putting that on the list. And they said,

1565.text:
no, we should. And here's how we know. And
they pointed to learning. They pointed to

1569.text:
self-efficacy. They could show us what it
did for student persistence. They said really,

1574.text:
high-impact practice, you shouldn't be fussy
about where that originates. If it has the

1581.text:
impact, it is high-impact. And we want to
get strategic about taking those transformational

1588.text:
experiences and getting them to the students
who most benefit. So if it's transformational,

1594.text:
it goes on the list. I love that. And I would
bet you guys have some things here that are

1599.text:
not in the national literature that you could
put on a pie chart like that. We were so impressed

1608.text:
we went and raised money from the Gates Foundation
to get another eight campuses to go through

1613.text:
the same exercise. And so they did. They each
came up with distinctive programs of their

1622.text:
own that they thought belonged in their PeopleSoft
records. And then we correlated them to those

1630.text:
taxonomies you saw earlier. With key numbers
so that we could keep track system-wide of

1637.text:
what seemed to be having the most benefit.
In all candor, because we're among friends,

1642.text:
the results were a mess. It didn't really
tell us what we wanted it to. We're probably

1646.text:
not going to try it again. But you can. I
do think this methodology has some things

1654.text:
going for it at the institutional level at
an individual campus, a university. When you

1658.text:
try rolling it up and see, let's look across
23 wildly different universities and see what

1664.text:
patterns we find, well, you don't find patterns.
What you find is wildly different universities.

1673.text:
But there's that record management step. And
as you know if you've done assessment work,

1680.text:
or even social science research generally,
what we have there is the outline of a really

1686.text:
beneficial feedback loop. Where the record
management we have confidence in. Because

1696.text:
at the time the record was created, we had
first developed a shared understanding of

1700.text:
what it means to do study abroad. What it
means to do service learning. What it doesn't

1705.text:
mean. Then we can track it with student records
disaggregated by demographics. And then we

1712.text:
can tell our assessment story with confidence
about what the benefits were. And use that

1735.text:
This is one of those other things that haunts
me, along with the students who don't graduate

1739.text:
but should. As we get systematic and intentional
with high-impact practices, as we surface

1746.text:
these things that have lived and thrived in
the shadows, we want to be careful not to

1751.text:
kill them. Right? What if the fact that they
were below the radar all these years, the

1759.text:
people who cared deeply about students and
have been left alone to work privately, what

1764.text:
if that's why they worked? What if as soon
as we shine a light on it and go, "Congratulations!

1770.text:
You're what Fresno State University cares
about!" You've just killed it. Now all of

1775.text:
a sudden they're supposed to follow some taxonomy.
When before they'd always been flying by the

1779.text:
seat of their pants. It's a risk. So we want
to be careful that the things we describe

1784.text:
that we care about are accurate reflections
of what happens. And also that we're still

1790.text:
allowing for professional discretion. Those
judgment calls. That shift at the last minute

1796.text:
when you see the look on the student's face
that tells you you shouldn't have said it

1802.text:
that way. And we want to keep it flexible,
right? That just in time adjusting to the

1808.text:
people that you're educating. On the other
hand, getting intentional, systematic research-driven

1815.text:
about how we engage students comes with an
ocean of benefits. We could build it into

1823.text:
degree requirements. As you guys launch your
strategic plan and then figure out how to

1828.text:
operationalize it, you may find yourselves
doing that. A lot of campuses are. I would

1833.text:
say at this point probably half of the CSU's
have committed themselves to giving some number

1838.text:
of high-impact practices to all students.
As soon as you do that, if you mean it, you've

1845.text:
got to now build it into a degree audit. So
you know if they got it. And that means you

1848.text:
need those good definitions. So that's kind
of where we're moving. And then it can count

1854.text:
for transfer credit. Then that 60% who started
somewhere else aren't left in the cold. Another

1865.text:
benefit, probably of more interest to me than
you, as we run up the end we can really start

1871.text:
to prove that stuff. Not just on survey data,
but on real evidence. But then finally, getting

1879.text:
back to our moon shot, there's the equity
piece. If we can define and support our feelings

1889.text:
about these high-impact practices with enough
consistency, then we can start to aim them

1895.text:
at the students who are most going to benefit.
And the research shows those are the same

1902.text:
students who are the least likely to opt-in.
So if you say, here's this really cool undergraduate

1909.text:
research project. Who wants to do it? You
know who's going to step forward. Let's get

1916.text:
the ones who don't. That's what work like
this enables. So that's the big question that

1929.text:
I think most of us are asking themselves.
How do you optimize that balance between the

1935.text:
costs and the benefits? So that we're still
nimble, we're still responsive, we're still

1938.text:
trusting professional judgment. But we have
leveraged our size and our diversity to really

1946.text:
learn intentionally how to do better. Which
gets us to that equity point. And one story

1957.text:
in particular at Fresno that I want to tell,
just because I'm so danged proud of it. That's

1967.text:
a student career undergraduate lower division,
where some high-impact practices seem to be

1975.text:
ideal. Undergraduate upper division, where
you could see some other high-impact practices

1981.text:
having particular bite. And then graduate
students. That we often forget about when

1989.text:
we talk about student success. You know, the
IPEDS reports that we give to the trustees,

1993.text:
we never talk about graduate students. But
college, like you know, that's becoming a

1999.text:
minimum education for the middle class. That
is what high school was two generations ago.

2005.text:
Well, in the same way, grad school is what
college was two generations ago. And a lot

2011.text:
of the students in grad school who wouldn't
have been there in their grandparents' time,

2017.text:
need help. They need these support structures.
They need these engaging experiences to remind

2024.text:
them before they drop out that this is relevant
and valuable learning. And at that end, you

2030.text:
could see learning communities, peer mentoring,
public sphere pedagogy. What's not on that

2034.text:
list is supplemental instruction, because
it runs all the way across. All the way across.

2040.text:
And that is a Fresno success story, as you
may know. I don't know how high a profile

2046.text:
it has on your campus. It has a pretty high
profile in the State. That's a picture from

2053.text:
one of its sessions. We had this conference
coming up at Fullerton at the end of April.

2065.text:
Tasha Giuffrida [assumed] will be there with
her team, presenting on some of the things

2068.text:
that have been happening here with supplemental
instruction. It's got a couple of different

2072.text:
listings in the preliminary program that we've
been publishing around early alert. And that

2081.text:
session title is, "Eliminating the Achievement
Gap" at Fresno. Not "closing." "Eliminating"

2090.text:
the Achievement Gap. And the thing that impresses
me about what Tasha's done is driving with

2100.text:
the lights on. Is really keeping track of
who's coming in, what are they getting, what's

2107.text:
the benefit, what does it do for their grades?
How many visits is enough visits? And what's

2113.text:
the difference in GPA tracked relative to
the number of visits for supplemental instruction?

2120.text:
Because now we can optimize our resources.
It's really, really cool. And there's our

2129.text:
moon shot, right? We knew we could do it.
And we are.

2147.text:
There's another project here that I want to
talk about. But before I do, I want to emphasize

2154.text:
that even though I've done all the talking
and I didn't even stop and ask you, get it?

2159.text:
Anyone want to ask me a question? I am here
for the rest of the day and I do want to learn

2163.text:
from you. And if we don't get the chance to
interact in person, a couple of slides from

2168.text:
now I'm going to put up a link to a blog I
have which has my contact information. And

2172.text:
I would love to get feedback from you, either
now or after it's sunk in. Or if you see something

2177.text:
that completely undermines all of the arguments
I've been making. You go, oh, actually, you

2181.text:
didn't think of such-and-such. I would love
to know that, I really would. So I will give

2185.text:
you that link in a moment. But first one more
Fresno story that I'm very fond of. About

2191.text:
two years ago we got a grant from the Helmsley
Charitable Trust for about $5 million to improve

2198.text:
STEM education in the first year. And the
premise of that project was, that's when the

2205.text:
students leave. They come in declaring STEM,
they're all excited out of high school. They

2210.text:
get their first taste of it with us and they
go huh, maybe I'd like to major in something

2216.text:
else. And it's true nationally. Not just in
the CSU. That if we could just hold onto all

2222.text:
of the people who declare STEM, the nation
would have all the STEM degree holders that

2228.text:
it needs. And it would be a diverse pool.
We don't have to do any more recruiting. We

2235.text:
don't have to do any more outreach. We just
have to do something better while they're

2239.text:
here. So they don't leave. Some of them will
anyway. Some of them were never born to be

2245.text:
STEM majors. And that's valid. But we have
this nagging sense that a lot of them who

2249.text:
go could have made it. But, you know, if you're
in those majors, you know what that's like.

2255.text:
Those first classes, it's like, I know you
love science. But first you really have to

2259.text:
learn calculus. And you're like, ugh. So this
project, STEM collaboratives, we only had

2272.text:
enough money to fund it on eight campuses.
Every campus in the CSU except two applied.

2278.text:
Fresno was one of the eight selected. So you
are a STEM collaborative demonstration site.

2284.text:
Students come here the summer before their
freshman year. And they do original research.

2289.text:
That's a heat map of your campus. The students
found that out by running around your campus

2295.text:
with thermometers, watches, smart phones.
And then they presented the findings to each

2304.text:
other in a public setting, legitimizing -- this
is all before the first day of class as a

2310.text:
freshman. Legitimizing what they had learned.
That's their presentation. The day that I

2316.text:
was here to see it, one of the students did
so well without using any notes that when

2321.text:
his parents came later to pick him up, he
did it all over again. In front of his parents.

2328.text:
In front of the rest of that cohort. Imagine
how those parents felt. I mean, that's college

2338.text:
at its best. At its best. And you're doing
that. So thank you. A lot. And please stay
